channel.title: Revolutions
channel.itunes:summary: A weekly podcast series examining great political revolutions. Now: The Haitian Revolution Next: Simon Bolivar and Gran Colombia. Visit us at revolutionspodcast.com
channel.itunes:author: Mike Duncan
channel.description: A weekly podcasting exploring great political revolutions. Now: The July Revolution. Next: 1848

item.title: 6.05- The Barricades
item.description: On Wed July 28, 1830 the people of Paris proved that piles of rubble were the key to urban revolution.
item.itunes:subtitle: On Wed July 28, 1830 the people of Paris proved that piles of rubble were the key to urban revolution.

item.title: 6.04- Stop The Presses
item.description: On Monday July 26, 1830 the Four Ordinances were published. On Tuesday July 27 the July Revolution began.
item.itunes:subtitle: On Monday July 26, 1830 the Four Ordinances were published. On Tuesday July 27 the July Revolution began.

item.title: 6.03- Help Yourself And Heaven Will Help You
item.description: In early 1830 King Charles X tried to beat back the liberal opposition. Instead they came back stronger than ever.
item.itunes:subtitle: In early 1830 King Charles X tried to beat back the liberal opposition. Instead they came back stronger than ever.

item.title: 6.02- Charles The Simple
item.description: After ascending to the throne in 1824 Charles X wanted to impose his ultra-royalism on France, but his annoying subjects kept resisting.
item.itunes:subtitle: After ascending to the throne in 1824 Charles X wanted to impose his ultra-royalism on France, but his annoying subjects kept resisting.

item.title: 6.01- The Chain of Time
item.description: After the fall of Napoleon, the Bourbon monarchy was restored.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the fall of Napoleon, the Bourbon monarchy was restored.

item.title: 5.27- The Labyrinth
item.description: In 1830, both Simon Bolivar and Gran Colombia died.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1830, both Simon Bolivar and Gran Colombia died.

item.title: 5.26- Out the Window
item.description: On Sept 25, 1828 Simón Bolívar went out the window.
item.itunes:subtitle: On Sept 25, 1828 Simón Bolívar went out the window.

item.title: 5.25- The Tangled Swords
item.description: At the end of 1826 Simon Bolivar returned to Colombia to deal with the revolt of Jose Antonio Paez.
item.itunes:subtitle: At the end of 1826 Simon Bolivar returned to Colombia to deal with the revolt of Jose Antonio Paez.

item.title: 5.24- The Republic of Bolivar
item.description: In 1825 Upper Peru became the independent nation of Bolivia.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1825 Upper Peru became the independent nation of Bolivia.

item.title: 5.23- Ayacucho
item.description: Wherein Gen. Sucre wins a very Bolivarian battle.
item.itunes:subtitle: Wherein Gen. Sucre wins a very Bolivarian battle.

item.title: 5.22- The Guayaquil Conference
item.description: Simòn Bolívar and Jose de San Martin met for the first and only time in July 1822
item.itunes:subtitle: Simòn Bolívar and Jose de San Martin met for the first and only time in July 1822

item.title: 5.21- The Third Sister
item.description:
In 1822, Antonio Jose Sucre and Simon Bolivar liberated Quito and made Gran Colombia whole.

Sponsor Link: Harrys Razors
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1822, Antonio Jose Sucre and Simon Bolivar liberated Quito and made Gran Colombia whole. Sponsor Link: Harrys Razors

item.title: Fundraiser Alert: Place Order By Nov 25 to Guarantee Delivery By Dec 23
item.description: Title kinda says it all.
item.itunes:subtitle: Title kinda says it all.

item.title: 5.20- The Sea Wolf
item.description: Lord Thomas Cochrane turned out to be the key to Peru.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lord Thomas Cochrane turned out to be the key to Peru.

item.title: 5.19- The Army of the Andes
item.description: José de San Martín gets zonked on opium and marches through the Andes.
item.itunes:subtitle: José de San Martín gets zonked on opium and marches through the Andes.

item.title: 5.18- Liberation
item.description:
On June 24, 1821 the Battle of Carabobo secured permanent independence for Venezuela.

http://revolutionspodcastfundraiser.com/
item.itunes:subtitle: On June 24, 1821 the Battle of Carabobo secured permanent independence for Venezuela. http://revolutionspodcastfundraiser.com/

item.title: 5.17a- Supplemental Gregor MacGregor
item.description: Do not buy land in Poyais.
item.itunes:subtitle: Do not buy land in Poyais.

item.title: 5.17- The Big Rock On The Side Of The Road
item.description:
In 1820 a mutiny in Cádiz changed the course of Spanish American history.

.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1820 a mutiny in Cádiz changed the course of Spanish American history. .

item.title: 5.16- Over The Mountains
item.description: In July 1819 Bolívar led a legendary march into the mountains to liberate New Granada once and for all.
item.itunes:subtitle: In July 1819 Bolívar led a legendary march into the mountains to liberate New Granada once and for all.

item.title: 5.15- The Centaur of the Plains
item.description: In January 1818 Simón Bolívar met José Antonio Páez. The War of Venezuelan Independence would never be the same.
item.itunes:subtitle: In January 1818 Simón Bolívar met José Antonio Páez. The War of Venezuelan Independence would never be the same.

item.title: 5.14- El Jefe Supremo
item.description: With an assist from the Republic of Haiti, Simon Bolivar launched a new expedition to Venezuela in 1816.
item.itunes:subtitle: With an assist from the Republic of Haiti, Simon Bolivar launched a new expedition to Venezuela in 1816.

item.title: 5.13- The Letter From Jamaica
item.description: Enter José de San Martín and Bernardo O'Higgins.
item.itunes:subtitle: Enter José de San Martín and Bernardo O'Higgins.

item.title: 5.12- The Desired One
item.description: The restoration of King Ferdinand VII spelled big trouble for Spanish American Independence.
item.itunes:subtitle: The restoration of King Ferdinand VII spelled big trouble for Spanish American Independence.

item.title: 5.11- The Legions of Hell
item.description: In 1814 Simón Bolívar met the Legions of Hell. It wasn't pretty.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1814 Simón Bolívar met the Legions of Hell. It wasn't pretty.

item.title: 5.10- War To The Death
item.description: Simón Bolívar left Venezuela in 1812. He came back in 1813.
item.itunes:subtitle: Simón Bolívar left Venezuela in 1812. He came back in 1813.

item.title: 5.09- God's Divine Wrath
item.description: Things did not go well for the First Venezuelan Republic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Things did not go well for the First Venezuelan Republic.

item.title: 5.08- The Patriotic Society For The Development of Agriculture and Livestock
item.description: in 1810 Simón Bolívar brought Francisco de Miranda home.
item.itunes:subtitle: in 1810 Simón Bolívar brought Francisco de Miranda home.

item.title: 5.07- The First Cry For Liberty
item.description: Further unrest plagued Spanish America in 1809 as the situation deteriorated back in Spain.
item.itunes:subtitle: Further unrest plagued Spanish America in 1809 as the situation deteriorated back in Spain.

item.title: 5.06- The Abdications of Bayonne
item.description: In May 1808 Napoleon deposed the Spanish Monarchy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In May 1808 Napoleon deposed the Spanish Monarchy.

item.title: 5.05- The Leander Expedition
item.description: 1n 1806, two invasions of South America tested the waters of independence. Also, Bolívar swears to liberate his country or die trying.
item.itunes:subtitle: 1n 1806, two invasions of South America tested the waters of independence. Also, Bolívar swears to liberate his country or die trying.

item.title: 5.04- The Prince of Caracas
item.description: Enter Bolívar.
item.itunes:subtitle: Enter Bolívar.

item.title: 5.01- The Conquest
item.description: After Columbus "discovered" America the Spanish built up an empire upon which the sun never set.
item.itunes:subtitle: After Columbus "discovered" America the Spanish built up an empire upon which the sun never set.

item.title: 5.03- The Precursors
item.description: After the Seven Years War the Spanish American Empire was hit with an array of revolts. Also six degrees of Francisco de Miranda.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Seven Years War the Spanish American Empire was hit with an array of revolts. Also six degrees of Francisco de Miranda.

item.title: 5.02- New Granada
item.description: After the Bourbons came to power they reformed the Spanish Empire and along the way created the Viceroyalty of New Granada.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Bourbons came to power they reformed the Spanish Empire and along the way created the Viceroyalty of New Granada.

item.title: 4.19- The History of Haiti
item.description: 1806-Present. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: 1806-Present. Enjoy.

item.title: 4.18- Death to the French
item.description: After declaring independence, Jean-Jacques Dessalines ordered the extermination of the white French.
item.itunes:subtitle: After declaring independence, Jean-Jacques Dessalines ordered the extermination of the white French.

item.title: 4.17a- The Haitian Declaration of Independence
item.description: Done at the headquarters of Gonaives, the first day of January 1804, the first year of independence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Done at the headquarters of Gonaives, the first day of January 1804, the first year of independence.

item.title: 4.17- Independence
item.description: The new nation of Haiti was born on New Years Day 1804.
item.itunes:subtitle: The new nation of Haiti was born on New Years Day 1804.

item.title: 4.16- Dying Like Flies
item.description: In the summer of 1802 the worst Yellow Fever epidemic on record hit Saint-Domingue--making it very difficult to re-impose slavery.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the summer of 1802 the worst Yellow Fever epidemic on record hit Saint-Domingue--making it very difficult to re-impose slavery.

item.title: 4.15- The Leclerc Expedition
item.description: With the massive expedition he assembled, Bonaparte reckoned it would take three months to retake Saint-Domingue.
item.itunes:subtitle: With the massive expedition he assembled, Bonaparte reckoned it would take three months to retake Saint-Domingue.

item.title: 4.14- The Constitution of 1801
item.description: In 1801 Toussaint Louverture annexed Santo Domingo and promulgated a new constitution without permission from France. First Consul Bonaparte was not amused.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1801 Toussaint Louverture annexed Santo Domingo and promulgated a new constitution without permission from France. First Consul Bonaparte was not amused.

item.title: 4.13- The War of Knives
item.description: From 1799-1800 Toussaint Louverture and Andre Rigaud fought a civil war for control of Saint-Domingue.
item.itunes:subtitle: From 1799-1800 Toussaint Louverture and Andre Rigaud fought a civil war for control of Saint-Domingue.

item.title: 4.12- Toussaint's Clause
item.description: Toussaint Louverture began to craft an independent foreign policy for Saint-Domingue in 1798.
item.itunes:subtitle: Toussaint Louverture began to craft an independent foreign policy for Saint-Domingue in 1798.

item.title: 4.11- To Attempt the Impossible
item.description: In 1797, Touissant used the conservative victory in the elections of Year V to solidify his own position in Saint-Domingue.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1797, Touissant used the conservative victory in the elections of Year V to solidify his own position in Saint-Domingue.

item.title: 4.10- The Third Commission
item.description: By mid-1796, Toussaint Louverture had no rival on Saint-Domingue. Then Sonthonax came back.
item.itunes:subtitle: By mid-1796, Toussaint Louverture had no rival on Saint-Domingue. Then Sonthonax came back.

item.title: 4.09- What The Future Will Bring
item.description: From the summer of 1794 to the summer of 1795, the future of Saint-Domingue hung in the balance.
item.itunes:subtitle: From the summer of 1794 to the summer of 1795, the future of Saint-Domingue hung in the balance.

item.title: 4.08- The Tricolor Commission
item.description: In February 1794, the National Convention not only ratified the emergency emancipation of the slaves, they extended it even further.
item.itunes:subtitle: In February 1794, the National Convention not only ratified the emergency emancipation of the slaves, they extended it even further.

item.title: 4.07- The Citizens of June 20
item.description: Le Cap burns. White colonial rule ends. The slaves are freed.
item.itunes:subtitle: Le Cap burns. White colonial rule ends. The slaves are freed.

item.title: 4.06- The Second Commission
item.description: The Second Commission was supposed to implement the Law of April 4 and defeat the slave uprising. This turned out to be harder than they thought.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Second Commission was supposed to implement the Law of April 4 and defeat the slave uprising. This turned out to be harder than they thought.

item.title: 4.05- The Citizens of April 4
item.description: With slave revolts and civil war erupting in Saint-Domingue, the Legislative Assembly abolished all racial distinctions on April 4, 1792.
item.itunes:subtitle: With slave revolts and civil war erupting in Saint-Domingue, the Legislative Assembly abolished all racial distinctions on April 4, 1792.

item.title: 4.04- Three Revolts
item.description: First the whites revolted. Then the free coloreds revolted. Then the slaves REALLY revolted.
item.itunes:subtitle: First the whites revolted. Then the free coloreds revolted. Then the slaves REALLY revolted.

item.title: 4.03- Free and Equal
item.description: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and the Citizen sure seemed to imply that men were born free and equal in rights. In fact, it explicitly said so.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and the Citizen sure seemed to imply that men were born free and equal in rights. In fact, it explicitly said so.

item.title: 4.02- The Web of Tension
item.description:
Wherein we find out what everyone thought about everyone else.

Direct Link: 4.02- The Web of Tension

Sponsor link: http://casper.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: Wherein we find out what everyone thought about everyone else. Direct Link: 4.02- The Web of Tension Sponsor link: http://casper.com/revolutions

item.title: 4.01- Saint-Domingue
item.description: The French colony of Saint-Domingue was the single most lucrative colony in the New World.
item.itunes:subtitle: The French colony of Saint-Domingue was the single most lucrative colony in the New World.

item.title: 3.55- The Retrospective
item.description: One last look back at the pile of severed heads.
item.itunes:subtitle: One last look back at the pile of severed heads.

item.description:
This is a real thing that is actually happening:

http://www.adweek.com/galleycat/podcast-host-mike-duncan-inks-book-deal/110975

item.title: 3.54- The Empire
item.description:
Napoleon conquered Europe. Then he got beat and the Bourbons came back.

Twitter: @mikeduncan
item.itunes:subtitle: Napoleon conquered Europe. Then he got beat and the Bourbons came back. Twitter: @mikeduncan

item.title: 3.53- The Consulate
item.description: After coming to power in 1799, First Consul Bonaparte achieved many of the Revolution's dreams and healed many of its open wounds. So he declared himself Emperor in 1804.
item.itunes:subtitle: After coming to power in 1799, First Consul Bonaparte achieved many of the Revolution's dreams and healed many of its open wounds. So he declared himself Emperor in 1804.

item.title: 3.52- There is Your Man
item.description:
And his name is Napoleon Bonaparte.

Sponsor Link: lynda.com/revolutions

Me on Twitter: twitter.com/mikeduncan
item.itunes:subtitle: And his name is Napoleon Bonaparte. Sponsor Link: lynda.com/revolutions Me on Twitter: twitter.com/mikeduncan

item.title: 3.51- The Coup of Prairial
item.description:
When the War of the Second Coalition got off to a terrible start for the French, the Triumvirate that had been running the Directory since 1797 was overthrown.

Hey look I'm on Twitter: https://twitter.com/mikeduncan
item.itunes:subtitle: When the War of the Second Coalition got off to a terrible start for the French, the Triumvirate that had been running the Directory since 1797 was overthrown. Hey look I'm on Twitter: https://twitter.com/mikeduncan

item.title: 3.50- The Second Coalition
item.description: While Bonaparte was off trying to conquer Egypt, the rest of Europe mobilized against France.
item.itunes:subtitle: While Bonaparte was off trying to conquer Egypt, the rest of Europe mobilized against France.

item.title: 3.49- The Egyptian Expedition
item.description: In July 1798 Bonaparte and his healthy, hopeful army arrived in Egypt. In August 1799 Bonaparte ditched his now demoralized, plague-ridden army and sailed for home.
item.itunes:subtitle: In July 1798 Bonaparte and his healthy, hopeful army arrived in Egypt. In August 1799 Bonaparte ditched his now demoralized, plague-ridden army and sailed for home.

item.title: 3.48- The Coup of Floreal
item.description: The Directory manipulated the elections of Year VI to block left-wing candidates. Meanwhile Talleyrand provoked the Americans into war and Bonaparte sailed for Egypt.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Directory manipulated the elections of Year VI to block left-wing candidates. Meanwhile Talleyrand provoked the Americans into war and Bonaparte sailed for Egypt.

item.title: 3.47- The Directorial Terror
item.description:
After Fructidor the Directory cracked down on the conservatives. They also created more sister republicans to systematically loot.

Sponsor Link: http://lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: After Fructidor the Directory cracked down on the conservatives. They also created more sister republicans to systematically loot. Sponsor Link: http://lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.46- The Coup of Fructidor
item.description: After taking a drubbing in the elections Year V, the Directory decided to just annul the results.
item.itunes:subtitle: After taking a drubbing in the elections Year V, the Directory decided to just annul the results.

item.title: 3.45- The Fall of Mantua
item.description:
Bonaparte almost gets beat! But then he doesn't. Also don't invade Ireland in December.

sponsor link: http://lynda.com/revolutions.
item.itunes:subtitle: Bonaparte almost gets beat! But then he doesn't. Also don't invade Ireland in December. sponsor link: http://lynda.com/revolutions.

item.title: 3.44- The War Feeds Itself
item.description:
Control the central position. Move on the rear. Live off the land.

Sponsor Link: http://lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: Control the central position. Move on the rear. Live off the land. Sponsor Link: http://lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.43- The Conspiracy of Equals
item.description: The adventures of everyone's favorite proto-communist. k
item.itunes:subtitle: The adventures of everyone's favorite proto-communist. k

item.title: 3.42- The Whiff of Grapeshot
item.description: When the Thermidorean Convention introduced the Constitution of Year III, the political Right went a little nuts.
item.itunes:subtitle: When the Thermidorean Convention introduced the Constitution of Year III, the political Right went a little nuts.

item.title: 3.41- Bread and the Constitution of 1793
item.description: That's the slogan that rallied the last remnents of the sans culottes to action...right before they got crushed by the Thermidorean Convention.
item.itunes:subtitle: That's the slogan that rallied the last remnents of the sans culottes to action...right before they got crushed by the Thermidorean Convention.

item.title: 3.40- The Frozen Rivers
item.description: The terrible winter of 1794-95 helped France push back all her enemies. Also...Poland!
item.itunes:subtitle: The terrible winter of 1794-95 helped France push back all her enemies. Also...Poland!

item.title: 3.39- The Death of the Jacobins
item.description: After the events of 9 Thermidor, the Revolution began to swing back to the right.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the events of 9 Thermidor, the Revolution began to swing back to the right.

item.title: Help Scott Help Syria
item.description:
Promoting a fundraising drive spearheaded by Scott Chesworth at the Ancient World podcast to help preseve Syria's massively important cultural treasures.

item.title: 3.38- Thermidor
item.description: The events of 9 Thermidor II brought Act I of the French Revolution to a gruesome end.
item.itunes:subtitle: The events of 9 Thermidor II brought Act I of the French Revolution to a gruesome end.

item.title: 3.37- The Republic of Virtue
item.description: If the mainspring of popular government in peacetime is virtue, amid revolution it is at once virtue and terror: virtue, without which terror is fatal; terror, without which virtue is impotent.
item.itunes:subtitle: If the mainspring of popular government in peacetime is virtue, amid revolution it is at once virtue and terror: virtue, without which terror is fatal; terror, without which virtue is impotent.

item.title: 3.36- The Liquidation Process
item.description:
In the spring of 1794. the Revolution devoured a few of her most beloved children.

sponsor link: lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: In the spring of 1794. the Revolution devoured a few of her most beloved children. sponsor link: lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.35- The Law of 14 Frimaire
item.description: At the end of 1793, the Committee of Public Safety completed it's consolidation of power.
item.itunes:subtitle: At the end of 1793, the Committee of Public Safety completed it's consolidation of power.

item.title: 3.34c- Citizen Genet
item.description:
Do not get into a popularity contest with George Washington.

spnsor link: lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.34a- The Republican Calendar
item.description: In Oct 1793 the French Revolution took a stab at reforming time itself.
item.itunes:subtitle: In Oct 1793 the French Revolution took a stab at reforming time itself.

item.title: 3.34- Saturn's Children
item.description: In October 1793 the Reign of Terror got started with the executions of Marie Antoinette and the Girondins.
item.itunes:subtitle: In October 1793 the Reign of Terror got started with the executions of Marie Antoinette and the Girondins.

item.title: 3.33- The Geography of Terror
item.description:
In the fall of 1793, the French Republic started to gain traction against its enemies. Setting up the stage for the Reign of Terror.

sponsor: lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: In the fall of 1793, the French Republic started to gain traction against its enemies. Setting up the stage for the Reign of Terror. sponsor: lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.32- The Committee of Public Safety
item.description: In the summer of 1793 a re-organized Committee of Public Safety began to consolidate power.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the summer of 1793 a re-organized Committee of Public Safety began to consolidate power.

item.title: 3.31- The Man of Blood Part Deux
item.description: In the summer of 1793 the Revolutionaries in Paris were besieged from all sides.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the summer of 1793 the Revolutionaries in Paris were besieged from all sides.

item.title: 3.29- The Purge of the Girondins
item.description: On May 31-June 2, 1793 Paris once again rose in armed insurrection against the national government.
item.itunes:subtitle: On May 31-June 2, 1793 Paris once again rose in armed insurrection against the national government.

item.description:
In the spring of 1793 revolts against Paris started erupting all over France.

item.description: After the Battle of Valmy the French armies advanced on all fronts.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Battle of Valmy the French armies advanced on all fronts.

item.description: King Louis XVI was put on trial by the National Convention and executed Jan 21, 1793.

item.title: 3.25- The National Convention
item.description:
The National Convention voted unanimously to abolish the monarchy on Sept 21, 1792. Then they proceeded to go at each others throats.

item.title: The Flight of Emperor Palpatine
item.description: Would really like to get my hands on the salacious limericks the good Emperor composed while whacked on spice.
item.itunes:subtitle: Would really like to get my hands on the salacious limericks the good Emperor composed while whacked on spice.

item.title: 3.18- The Flight to Varennes
item.description:
In June 1791 the royal family tried to escape from Paris, but they were busted while passing through Verennes.

Sponsor link: lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: In June 1791 the royal family tried to escape from Paris, but they were busted while passing through Verennes. Sponsor link: lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.17- A Temporary Summit
item.description: After the Feast of the Federation, Revolutionary France was outwardly calm, but internally divided.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Feast of the Federation, Revolutionary France was outwardly calm, but internally divided.

item.title: 3.16- The Society of 1789
item.description: In the leadup to the great Fête de la Fédération, the Marquis de Lafayette and a group of liberal nobles began to direct the course of the Revolution.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the leadup to the great Fête de la Fédération, the Marquis de Lafayette and a group of liberal nobles began to direct the course of the Revolution.

item.title: 3.15- The Rise of the Jacobins
item.description: After the move to Paris, radical delegates from the National Assembly formed a new political club to help push their agenda.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the move to Paris, radical delegates from the National Assembly formed a new political club to help push their agenda.

item.title: 3.14- The Women's March on Versailles
item.description:
In October 1789 some angry houswives changed the course of the French Revolution.

Sponsor Link: lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: In October 1789 some angry houswives changed the course of the French Revolution. Sponsor Link: lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.13a- The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
item.description: Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Enjoy.

item.title: 3.13- The Rights of Man
item.description: After the Night of August 4th, the National Assembly divided into new political factions.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Night of August 4th, the National Assembly divided into new political factions.

item.title: 3.12- The Great Fear
item.description: After a wave of chaos spread across France, the National Assembly abolished feudalism on the night of Aug. 4, 1789.
item.itunes:subtitle: After a wave of chaos spread across France, the National Assembly abolished feudalism on the night of Aug. 4, 1789.

item.title: 3.11- The Fall of the Bastille
item.description: On July 14, 1789 a mob of angry Parisians stormed the Bastille.
item.itunes:subtitle: On July 14, 1789 a mob of angry Parisians stormed the Bastille.

item.title: Random Insert-Tour Announcement
item.description: English, French and American Revolutions Tours! Spring 2015!
item.itunes:subtitle: English, French and American Revolutions Tours! Spring 2015!

item.title: 3.10- The Tennis Court Oath
item.description:
On Day 2 of the Estates General, the Third Estate went on strike.

Sponsor link: Lynda.com/revolutions
item.itunes:subtitle: On Day 2 of the Estates General, the Third Estate went on strike. Sponsor link: Lynda.com/revolutions

item.title: 3.9- What is the Third Estate?
item.description: The debate over the coming Estates General awakened the political consciousness of the Third Estate. Also the weather was rotten.
item.itunes:subtitle: The debate over the coming Estates General awakened the political consciousness of the Third Estate. Also the weather was rotten.

item.title: 3.8- The Day of the Tiles
item.description: The king's attempt to break the Parments in the summer of 1788 was was met by widespread resistence.
item.itunes:subtitle: The king's attempt to break the Parments in the summer of 1788 was was met by widespread resistence.

item.title: 3.6- The Stately Quadrille
item.description: Round and round and round it goes...
item.itunes:subtitle: Round and round and round it goes...

item.title: 3.5- The Assembly of Notables
item.description: King Louis called the Assembly of Notables in early 1787 to approve a major fincancial reform package. But intead of rubber stamping the initiatives, the Notables scrutinized every detail.
item.itunes:subtitle: King Louis called the Assembly of Notables in early 1787 to approve a major fincancial reform package. But intead of rubber stamping the initiatives, the Notables scrutinized every detail.

item.title: 3.4- Necker and the Necklace
item.description: Just as the financial situation was about to explode the monarchy was hit by a public relations nightmare.
item.itunes:subtitle: Just as the financial situation was about to explode the monarchy was hit by a public relations nightmare.

item.title: 3.3- Resistance to Reform
item.description: As power passed from Louis XV to Louis XVI, royal ministers attempted to implement reforms, but were thewarted at every turn.
item.itunes:subtitle: As power passed from Louis XV to Louis XVI, royal ministers attempted to implement reforms, but were thewarted at every turn.

item.title: 3.2-The Broken Regime
item.description: The Ancien Regime was a mess in desperate need of reform.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ancien Regime was a mess in desperate need of reform.

item.title: 3.1- The Three Estates
item.description: The population of pre-Revolutionary France was divided into Three Estates: the Church, the Nobility and Everyone Else.
item.itunes:subtitle: The population of pre-Revolutionary France was divided into Three Estates: the Church, the Nobility and Everyone Else.

item.title: 3.0 Revolutions Podcast Update
item.description: Tours. Episode Numbering. Money. Parlez-vous français?
item.itunes:subtitle: Tours. Episode Numbering. Money. Parlez-vous français?

item.title: 2.15a- The Bill of Rights
item.description: Hang them on the wall of every classroom.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hang them on the wall of every classroom.

item.title: 2.15- The Rising Sun
item.description: The ratification of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights marks the end of the Revolutionary Era.
item.itunes:subtitle: The ratification of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights marks the end of the Revolutionary Era.

item.title: 2.14- The Critical Period
item.description: Between the end of the War of Independence and the Constitutional Convention the new United States was plagued by problems. The Articles of Confederation were not up to solving them.
item.itunes:subtitle: Between the end of the War of Independence and the Constitutional Convention the new United States was plagued by problems. The Articles of Confederation were not up to solving them.

item.title: 2.13- The Articles of Confederation
item.description: As the newly independent United States trasitioned from war to peace, it was tripped up by the ineffective Articles of Confederation.
item.itunes:subtitle: As the newly independent United States trasitioned from war to peace, it was tripped up by the ineffective Articles of Confederation.

item.title: 2.12- Yorktown
item.description: Lord Cornwallis was trapped in Yorktown in October 1781. His surrender ended the American War of Independence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lord Cornwallis was trapped in Yorktown in October 1781. His surrender ended the American War of Independence.

item.title: 2.11- Tarleton's Quarter
item.description: Despite the thrashing he gave Horatio Gates at the Battle of Camden, Lord Cornwallis found the Carolinas slipping out of his grasp.
item.itunes:subtitle: Despite the thrashing he gave Horatio Gates at the Battle of Camden, Lord Cornwallis found the Carolinas slipping out of his grasp.

item.title: 2.10- Turning South
item.description: The Episode That Wouldn't Die.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Episode That Wouldn't Die.

item.title: 2.9- Valley Forge
item.description: After Saratoga the French joined the war, the British changed strategies and Washington's army spent a miserable winter at Valley Forge.
item.itunes:subtitle: After Saratoga the French joined the war, the British changed strategies and Washington's army spent a miserable winter at Valley Forge.

item.title: 2.8- Saratoga
item.description: Gentleman Johnny's Party Train ran into some trouble in 1777.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gentleman Johnny's Party Train ran into some trouble in 1777.

item.title: 2.7- Crossing the Delaware
item.description: With the revolution on the line, George Washginton led his army to victory at Trenton. Unfortunately he would be unable to stop the British from taking Philadelphia in 1777.
item.itunes:subtitle: With the revolution on the line, George Washginton led his army to victory at Trenton. Unfortunately he would be unable to stop the British from taking Philadelphia in 1777.

item.title: 2.6a- Supplemental The Declaration of Independence
item.description: When in the course of human events...
item.itunes:subtitle: When in the course of human events...

item.title: 2.6- Independence
item.description: The American colonies declared independence in July 1776. Then their armies got chased around New York.
item.itunes:subtitle: The American colonies declared independence in July 1776. Then their armies got chased around New York.

item.title: 2.5- The Guns of Ticonderoga
item.description: After the skirmishes at Lexington and Concord, war between Britain and the colonies broke out. George Washington was appointed commander-in-chief and laid siege to Boston.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the skirmishes at Lexington and Concord, war between Britain and the colonies broke out. George Washington was appointed commander-in-chief and laid siege to Boston.

item.title: 2.4- The Boston Tea Party
item.description: The Boston Tea Party led Parliament to pass the Intolerable Acts in 1774. The colonists were really super not amused.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Boston Tea Party led Parliament to pass the Intolerable Acts in 1774. The colonists were really super not amused.

item.title: 2.3- The Townshend Acts
item.description: After the failure of the Stamp Act, Parliament passed a new series of taxes known as the Townshend Acts. The colonists were not amused.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the failure of the Stamp Act, Parliament passed a new series of taxes known as the Townshend Acts. The colonists were not amused.

item.title: 2.2- The Stamp Act
item.description: After the French and Indian War, the British Ministry started levying new taxes on the colonies. The colonists were not amused.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the French and Indian War, the British Ministry started levying new taxes on the colonies. The colonists were not amused.

item.title: 2.1- The Thirteen Colonies
item.description: A brief tour of the Thirteen Colonies.
item.itunes:subtitle: A brief tour of the Thirteen Colonies.

item.title: 1.16- The Restoration
item.description: The English Monarchy was restored in 1660.
item.itunes:subtitle: The English Monarchy was restored in 1660.

item.title: 1.16a Supplemental- Sir Edward Hyde, First Earl of Clarendon
item.description: After serving in Parliament and the courts of both Charles I and Charles II, Edward Hyde wrote a massively influential history of the English Civil Wars.
item.itunes:subtitle: After serving in Parliament and the courts of both Charles I and Charles II, Edward Hyde wrote a massively influential history of the English Civil Wars.

item.title: 1.15- The Good Old Cause
item.description: Oliver Cromwell died on September 3, 1658. His son and heir Richard was iunable to hold the Protectorate together.
item.itunes:subtitle: Oliver Cromwell died on September 3, 1658. His son and heir Richard was iunable to hold the Protectorate together.

item.title: 1.14a Supplemental- The War on Christmas
item.description: After the Puritans came to power they tried to abolish Christmas. Seriously.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Puritans came to power they tried to abolish Christmas. Seriously.

item.title: 1.14- The Humble Petition and Advice
item.description: The dissolution of the First Protectorate Parliament led to the brief and unpopular Rule of the Major Generals. When the Second Protectorate Parliament was finally called they tried to make Oliver Cromwell king.
item.itunes:subtitle: The dissolution of the First Protectorate Parliament led to the brief and unpopular Rule of the Major Generals. When the Second Protectorate Parliament was finally called they tried to make Oliver Cromwell king.

item.title: 1.13- The Instrument of Government
item.description: The Instrument of Government was the first written constituion in English history.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Instrument of Government was the first written constituion in English history.

item.title: 1.12- In The Name of God Go
item.description: In 1653 Oliver Cromwell dissolved the Rump Parliament and then Barebone's Parliament dissolved itself. The Commonwealth was not getting off to a great start.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1653 Oliver Cromwell dissolved the Rump Parliament and then Barebone's Parliament dissolved itself. The Commonwealth was not getting off to a great start.

item.title: 1.12b- Supplemental The Diggers
item.description: God wanted me to tell you that property is theft.
item.itunes:subtitle: God wanted me to tell you that property is theft.

item.title: 1.12a- Supplemental Freeborn John
item.description: For someone who was born free John Lilburne sure spent a lot of time in prison
item.itunes:subtitle: For someone who was born free John Lilburne sure spent a lot of time in prison

item.title: 1.11a- Tour Announcement 2
item.description: Reserve your spot for England/France June 2014 at www.historyworldtravel.com!
item.itunes:subtitle: Reserve your spot for England/France June 2014 at www.historyworldtravel.com!

item.title: 1.11- The Crowning Mercy
item.description: Charles II raised an army of Scots to help him claim the throne, but they were defeated by Oliver Cromwell at Dunbar and Worcester.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles II raised an army of Scots to help him claim the throne, but they were defeated by Oliver Cromwell at Dunbar and Worcester.

item.title: 1.10- Regicide
item.description: After Pride's Purge, Charles I was executed by the Rump Parliament on January 30, 1649. Then Cromwell invaded Ireland.
item.itunes:subtitle: After Pride's Purge, Charles I was executed by the Rump Parliament on January 30, 1649. Then Cromwell invaded Ireland.

item.title: 1.9- The Man of Blood
item.description: As the New Model Army debated the merits of constitutional democracy, King Charles was scheming to put himself back on the throne.
item.itunes:subtitle: As the New Model Army debated the merits of constitutional democracy, King Charles was scheming to put himself back on the throne.

item.title: 1.8- Checkmate
item.description: After the Battle of Naseby ended the King's chances for military victory, he became the frustrating center of post-war negotiations.
item.itunes:subtitle: After the Battle of Naseby ended the King's chances for military victory, he became the frustrating center of post-war negotiations.

item.title: 1.7a- Tour Announcement
item.description: New Revolutions Tour coming in June 2014! Email: tours@revolutionspodcast.com
item.itunes:subtitle: New Revolutions Tour coming in June 2014! Email: tours@revolutionspodcast.com

item.title: 1.7- The New Model Army
item.description: After years of muddling along, Parliament created a more professional army. They finally defeated King Charles at Nasbay in June 1645.
item.itunes:subtitle: After years of muddling along, Parliament created a more professional army. They finally defeated King Charles at Nasbay in June 1645.

item.title: 1.6- The Solemn League And Covenant
item.description: In late 1643, Parliament sealed a military alliance with the Scots. Their combined force defeated the Royalists at Marston Moor.
item.itunes:subtitle: In late 1643, Parliament sealed a military alliance with the Scots. Their combined force defeated the Royalists at Marston Moor.

item.title: 1.5- Cavaliers and Roundheads
item.description: After negotiations with Parliament broke down, King Charles raised his standard in August, 1642. The opening campaigns of the First Civil War tilted in the Royalists favor.
item.itunes:subtitle: After negotiations with Parliament broke down, King Charles raised his standard in August, 1642. The opening campaigns of the First Civil War tilted in the Royalists favor.

item.title: 1.5a- Supplemental- The Armies
item.description: A brief description of the soldiers who fought in the English Civil Wars.
item.itunes:subtitle: A brief description of the soldiers who fought in the English Civil Wars.

item.title: 1.4- The Long Parliament
item.description: The Long Parliament convened in November 1640. Tensions ran high as Parliamentary leaders tried to assert control over the State.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Long Parliament convened in November 1640. Tensions ran high as Parliamentary leaders tried to assert control over the State.

item.title: 1.3- The Bishops' Wars
item.description: The Scots revolted after Charles tried to impose the Book of Common Prayer, forcing the King to recall Parliament.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Scots revolted after Charles tried to impose the Book of Common Prayer, forcing the King to recall Parliament.

item.title: 1.2- Personal Rule
item.description: In the 1630s, King Charles ruled without Parliament. His financial policies and religious innovations annoyed many of his subjects.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the 1630s, King Charles ruled without Parliament. His financial policies and religious innovations annoyed many of his subjects.

item.title: 1.1- The Kingdoms of Charles Stuart
item.description: In 1625 Charles Stuart became king of England, Scotland and Ireland. His relationship with Parliament immediately got off on the wrong foot.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1625 Charles Stuart became king of England, Scotland and Ireland. His relationship with Parliament immediately got off on the wrong foot.

item.title: 0.0- Introduction
item.description: Welcome to Revolutions.
item.itunes:subtitle: Welcome to Revolutions.
